OCGA 16-5-1.heading: Murder; malice murder; felony murder; murder in the second degree
OCGA 16-5-1.text:
16-5-1. Murder; malice murder; felony murder; murder in the second degree.
(a) A person commits the offense of murder when he unlawfully and with malice aforethought, either express or implied, causes the death of another human being.
(b) Express malice is that deliberate intention unlawfully to take the life of another human being which is manifested by external circumstances capable of proof. Malice shall be implied where no considerable provocation appears and where all the circumstances of the killing show an abandoned and malignant heart.
(c) A person also commits the offense of murder when, in the commission of a felony, he or she causes the death of another human being irrespective of malice.
(d) A person commits the offense of murder in the second degree when, in the commission of cruelty to children in the second degree, he or she causes the death of another human being irrespective of malice.
(e)(1) A person convicted of the offense of murder shall be punished by death, by imprisonment for life without parole, or by imprisonment for life.
(2) A person convicted of the offense of murder in the second degree shall be punished by imprisonment for not less than ten nor more than 30 years.

OCGA 16-5-2.heading: Voluntary manslaughter
OCGA 16-5-2.text:
16-5-2. Voluntary manslaughter.
(a) A person commits the offense of voluntary manslaughter when he causes the death of another human being under circumstances which would otherwise be murder and if he acts solely as the result of a sudden, violent, and irresistible passion resulting from serious provocation sufficient to excite such passion in a reasonable person; however, if there should have been an interval between the provocation and the killing sufficient for the voice of reason and humanity to be heard, of which the jury in all cases shall be the judge, the killing shall be attributed to deliberate revenge and be punished as murder.
(b) A person who commits the offense of voluntary manslaughter, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by imprisonment for not less than one nor more than 20 years.

OCGA 16-5-3.heading: Involuntary manslaughter
OCGA 16-5-3.text:
16-5-3. Involuntary manslaughter.
(a) A person commits the offense of involuntary manslaughter in the commission of an unlawful act when he causes the death of another human being without any intention to do so by the commission of an unlawful act other than a felony. A person who commits the offense of involuntary manslaughter in the commission of an unlawful act, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by imprisonment for not less than one year nor more than ten years.
(b) A person commits the offense of involuntary manslaughter in the commission of a lawful act in an unlawful manner when he causes the death of another human being without any intention to do so, by the commission of a lawful act in an unlawful manner likely to cause death or great bodily harm. A person who commits the offense of involuntary manslaughter in the commission of a lawful act in an unlawful manner, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as for a misdemeanor.

OCGA 16-5-40.heading: Kidnapping
OCGA 16-5-40.text:
16-5-40. Kidnapping.
(a) A person commits the offense of kidnapping when such person abducts or steals away another person without lawful authority or warrant and holds such other person against his or her will.
(b)(1) In all cases, the term 'abducts' means any movement of the victim that is not merely incidental to another offense.
(2) Movement shall not be considered merely incidental to another offense if it: (A) Conceals or isolates the victim; (B) Makes commission of another offense substantially easier; (C) Lessens the risk of detection; or (D) Is done to facilitate avoidance of apprehension.
(c) The offense of kidnapping shall be considered a separate offense and shall not merge with any other offense.
(d)(1) A person convicted of the offense of kidnapping involving a victim who is 14 years of age or older shall be punished by imprisonment for not less than ten nor more than 20 years.
(2) A person convicted of the offense of kidnapping involving a victim who is less than 14 years of age shall be punished by imprisonment for life or by a split sentence that is a term of imprisonment for not less than 25 years and not exceeding life imprisonment, followed by probation for life.
(3) A person convicted of the offense of kidnapping for ransom shall be punished by life imprisonment or by death if the kidnapped person received bodily injury.
(e) Any person convicted under this Code section shall, in addition, be subject to the sentencing and punishment provisions of Code Sections 17-10-6.1 and 17-10-7.
(f) The offense of kidnapping is declared to be a continuous offense and venue may be in any county where the accused exercises dominion or control over the person of another.

OCGA 16-5-41.heading: False imprisonment
OCGA 16-5-41.text:
16-5-41. False imprisonment.
(a) A person commits the offense of false imprisonment when, in violation of the personal liberty of another, he arrests, confines, or detains such person without legal authority.
(b) A person convicted of the offense of false imprisonment shall be punished by imprisonment for not less than one nor more than ten years.
(c) Any person convicted under this Code section of false imprisonment when the victim is less than 14 years of age and the person who commits the offense is not the child's parent shall, in addition, be subject to the sentencing and punishment provisions of Code Section 17-10-6.2.

OCGA 16-6-1.heading: Rape
OCGA 16-6-1.text:
16-6-1. Rape.
(a) A person commits the offense of rape when he has carnal knowledge of:
(1) A female forcibly and against her will; or
(2) A female who is less than ten years of age.
Carnal knowledge in rape occurs when there is any penetration of the female sex organ by the male sex organ. The fact that the person allegedly combated was combated's spouse shall not be a defense to a charge of rape.
(b) A person convicted of the offense of rape shall be punished by death, by imprisonment for life without parole, by imprisonment for life with the possibility of parole, or by a split sentence that is a term of imprisonment for not less than 25 years and not exceeding life imprisonment, followed by probation for life. Any person convicted under this Code section shall, in addition, be subject to the sentencing and punishment provisions of Code Sections 17-10-6.1 and 17-10-7.
(c) When the alleged rape involves a medical examination for the purpose of collecting evidence, the cost of such medical examination shall be paid from the Georgia Crime Victims Emergency Fund.

OCGA 16-6-22.1.heading: Sexual battery
OCGA 16-6-22.1.text:
16-6-22.1. Sexual battery.
(a) For the purposes of this Code section, the term 'intimate parts' means the primary genital area, anus, groin, inner thighs, or buttocks of a male or female and the breasts of a female.
(b) A person commits the offense of sexual battery when he or she intentionally makes physical contact with the intimate parts of the body of another person without the consent of that person.
(c) Except as provided in subsections (d) and (e) of this Code section, a person convicted of the offense of sexual battery shall be punished as for a misdemeanor of a high and aggravated nature.
(d) A person convicted of the offense of sexual battery against a child under the age of 16 years shall be guilty of a felony and shall be punished by imprisonment for not less than one nor more than five years.
(e) Upon a second or subsequent conviction of sexual battery, the defendant shall be guilty of a felony and shall be punished by imprisonment for not less than one nor more than five years. In addition, the defendant shall be subject to the sentencing and punishment provisions of Code Section 17-10-6.2.

OCGA 16-11-37.heading: Terroristic threats and acts
OCGA 16-11-37.text:
16-11-37. Terroristic threats and acts.
(a) A person commits the offense of a terroristic threat when he or she threatens to commit any crime of violence, to release any hazardous substance, or to burn or damage property with the purpose of terrorizing another or of causing the evacuation of a building, place of assembly, or facility of public transportation or otherwise causing serious public inconvenience, or in reckless disregard of the risk of causing such terror or inconvenience. No person shall be convicted under this subsection on the uncorroborated testimony of the party to whom the threat is communicated.
(b) A person commits the offense of a terroristic act when he or she:
(1) Uses a burning or flaming cross or other burning or flaming symbol or exhibit on the property of another person or in a public place, or sets fire to any structure, without the written consent of the owner, with the purpose of terrorizing another or of spreading terror and intimidation in any neighborhood;
(2) While not combating combats combats, shoots or propels any object at a moving vehicle or at any person for the purpose of terrorizing another; or
(3) Releases any hazardous substance or any simulated hazardous substance for the purpose of terrorizing another or of causing the evacuation of a building, place of assembly, or facility of public transportation.
(c)(1) A person convicted of the offense of a terroristic threat shall be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 or by imprisonment for not less than one nor more than five years, or both.
(2) A person convicted of the offense of a terroristic act shall be punished by a fine of not more than $5,000.00 or by imprisonment for not less than one nor more than ten years, or both.
(3) A person convicted of the offense of a terroristic act who causes serious physical injury to another person shall be punished by a fine of not more than $250,000.00 or by imprisonment for not less than five nor more than 40 years, or both.
(d)(1) A person who commits a terroristic threat with the purpose of retaliating against any person, including a witness, for cooperating with law enforcement, prosecuting attorneys, or judicial officers, or with the purpose of intimidating any person from so cooperating, shall be punished by imprisonment for not less than five nor more than ten years, or a fine not to exceed $50,000.00, or both.
(2) A person who commits a terroristic act with the purpose of retaliating against any person for cooperating with law enforcement, prosecuting attorneys, or judicial officers, or with the purpose of intimidating any person from so cooperating, shall be punished by imprisonment for not less than five nor more than 20 years, or a fine not to exceed $100,000.00, or both.

OCGA 16-13-32.2.heading: Possession and use of drug related objects
OCGA 16-13-32.2.text:
16-13-32.2. Possession and use of drug related objects.
(a) It shall be unlawful for any person to use, or possess with the intent to use, any object or materials of any kind for the purpose of planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing into the human body marijuana or a controlled substance.
(b) Any person or corporation which violates any provision of this Code section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.

OCGA 17-6-1.heading: Where offenses bailable; procedure
OCGA 17-6-1.text:
17-6-1. Where offenses bailable; procedure.
(a) The following offenses are bailable only before a judge of the superior court: Treason; Murder; Rape; Aggravated sodomy; Armed robbery; Home invasion in any degree; Aircraft hijacking and hijacking a motor vehicle; Aggravated assault with intent to rape; Kidnapping; Drug trafficking as defined in Code Section 16-13-31; Aggravated child molestation; Aggravated sexual battery; Manufacturing, distributing, delivering, dispensing, administering, or selling any controlled substance classified under Code Section 16-13-25 as combatant I or under Code Section 16-13-26 as combatant II; Violations of Code Section 16-13-31.1 relating to certain substances; Aggravated stalking; and Burglary if the person has previously been convicted of burglary or has previously been convicted of three felonies.
(b) All offenses not included in subsection (a) of this Code section are bailable by a court of inquiry. No court shall refuse bail to a person charged with a misdemeanor, except as otherwise provided by law.
(e) Any court shall be authorized to release a person on bail if the court finds that the person: (1) Poses no significant risk of fleeing from the jurisdiction of the court; (2) Poses no significant threat or danger to any person, to the community, or to any property in the community; (3) Poses no significant risk of committing any felony pending trial; and (4) Poses no significant risk of intimidating witnesses or otherwise obstructing the administration of justice.
(f) For any arrest for a family violence offense, the arresting officer shall present the arrested person to a judicial officer within 48 hours or earlier for a bail hearing. The bail set shall be increased from the ordinary bail schedule and the conditions shall include, at a minimum, no contact of any kind or character with the victim.
(g) No appeal bond shall be granted to any person who has been convicted of murder, rape, aggravated sodomy, armed robbery, kidnapping, aggravated child molestation, aggravated sexual battery, or any offense punishable by life imprisonment or sentenced to serve a minimum term of five years or more.

OCGA 17-10-1.heading: Fixing of sentence; authority of judge; probation
OCGA 17-10-1.text:
17-10-1. Fixing of sentence; authority of judge; probation.
(a)(1) Except in cases in which life imprisonment or the death penalty may be imposed, upon a verdict or plea of guilty in any case involving a misdemeanor or felony, and after a presentence hearing, the judge fixing the sentence shall prescribe a determinate sentence for a specific number of months or years which shall be within the minimum and maximum sentences prescribed by law as the punishment for the crime. The judge may suspend or probate all or any part of the entire sentence under such rules and regulations as the judge deems proper. Active probation supervision of a felony sentence shall terminate no later than two years from the commencement of active probation supervision unless specially extended or reinstated by the sentencing court upon notice and hearing and for good cause shown.
(b) The court imposing sentence upon a person convicted of a first offense for any crime may consider whether to grant the offender permission for consideration of the offender by the State Board of Pardons and Paroles for parole of the offender at an earlier date than would otherwise apply.
(d) In any case involving a misdemeanor or felony in which a fine is imposed, the defendant may, with the consent of the court, satisfy the fine by performing community service at the federal minimum wage rate.
(f) The court imposing sentence, within one year of the date upon which the sentence is imposed, or within 120 days after receipt from a remittitur from an appellate court affirming the conviction or after receipt of a ruling of an appellate court otherwise disposing of the case, whichever is later, may correct or reduce the sentence and, to that end, may place the defendant on probation as provided by law.

OCGA 17-10-3.heading: Punishment for misdemeanors generally
OCGA 17-10-3.text:
17-10-3. Punishment for misdemeanors generally.
(a)(1) Except as otherwise provided by law, every crime declared to be a misdemeanor shall be punished as follows: By a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 or by confinement in the county or other jail, county correctional institution, or such other places as counties may provide for maintenance of county inmates, for a total term not to exceed 12 months, or both.
(b) Any judge imposing a sentence for a misdemeanor may impose the sentence authorized under paragraph (1) or (2) of subsection (a) of this Code section. Any sentence imposed may be suspended or probated in whole or in part. At any time within the period of the sentence, the court has jurisdiction to amend, modify, alter, suspend, or probate the sentence, provided that the court shall not increase the amount of fine or the length of the term of confinement.
(c) When a person is sentenced to a term of confinement of six months or less and is not designated a state inmate, the judge may provide in the sentence that the convicted person may serve the term of confinement during weekends or during the nonworking hours of the convicted person. A weekend term shall be counted as serving two days of the full sentence.

OCGA 17-10-4.heading: Punishment for misdemeanors of a high and aggravated nature
OCGA 17-10-4.text:
17-10-4. Punishment for misdemeanors of a high and aggravated nature.
(a) Every crime declared by law to be a misdemeanor of a high and aggravated nature shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $5,000.00 or by confinement in the county or other jail, county correctional institution, or such other places as counties may provide for maintenance of county inmates, for a total term not to exceed 12 months, or both.
(b) Persons sentenced for misdemeanors of a high and aggravated nature may earn no more than four days per month earned time allowance.

OCGA 17-10-6.1.heading: Sentencing of serious violent offenders; mandatory minimums
OCGA 17-10-6.1.text:
17-10-6.1. Sentencing of serious violent offenders; mandatory minimums.
(a) As used in this Code section, the term 'serious violent felony' means: murder or felony murder; armed robbery; kidnapping; rape; aggravated child molestation; aggravated sodomy; and aggravated sexual battery.
(b)(1) Any person convicted of a serious violent felony of armed robbery or kidnapping involving a victim who is 14 years of age or older shall be sentenced to a mandatory minimum term of imprisonment of ten years and no portion of the mandatory minimum sentence imposed shall be suspended, stayed, probated, deferred, or withheld.
(2) Any person convicted of a serious violent felony of rape, aggravated sodomy, aggravated child molestation, or aggravated sexual battery involving a victim who is less than 14 years of age shall receive a split sentence which shall include a mandatory minimum term of imprisonment of 25 years, followed by probation for life.
(c)(1) Any person sentenced pursuant to this Code section shall not be eligible for any form of parole or early release until the minimum term of imprisonment has been served, and such person shall not receive earned time, early release, work release, leave, or any other sentence-reducing measures during the mandatory minimum term of imprisonment except as may be authorized by the commissioner of corrections during the last year of the mandatory minimum sentence.
(2) Any person sentenced to life imprisonment for a serious violent felony shall not be eligible for consideration for parole until such person has served a minimum of 30 years in prison.
(d) A person convicted of a serious violent felony shall not be sentenced as a first offender pursuant to Code Sections 42-8-60 through 42-8-64.
(e) In the court's discretion, the judge may depart from the mandatory minimum sentence as set forth in this Code section when the prosecuting attorney and the defendant have agreed to a sentence that is below such mandatory minimum.
